questions.text: A 34-year-old industrial worker develops nausea, vomiting, garlic odor on breath, and yellowish discoloration of the sclera. He dies after 3 days of illness. On autopsy, the liver is found to be enlarged, yellow, soft, and fatty. Which of the following poisons is most likely responsible?
questions.solution:
Explanation:
Phosphorus poisoning is associated with severe hepatotoxicity, characterized by:

  • Fatty change (steatosis) in the liver: Yellow, enlarged, soft, and greasy appearance.
  • Progression to acute yellow atrophy in severe cases.
  • Garlic odor in breath and gastric contents.
  • Luminescence of vomitus or stomach contents (due to elemental phosphorus).
  • Jaundice, coagulopathy, and multiorgan hemorrhages on postmortem.
  • Seen in rodenticides, fireworks, and industrial exposure.

Postmortem findings in phosphorus poisoning:

External

  1. Emaciation, purpuric haemorrhages in the skin, jaundice and the smell of garlic may be present.
  2. Mucous membrane of the mouth is corroded.
  3. Hypostasis is dark brown in color.

Internal

  1. Multiple haemorrhages are seen in the muscles, serosal and mucosal membranes of the GIT and respiratory tract, liver, kidneys, endocardium, pericardium, epicardium, peritoneum, lungs and brain.
  2. Stomach and intestines: Mucous membranes are yellowish or greyish white in colour, softened, thickened, inflamed and corroded in patches; luminous material may be found in the stomach. Contents may smell of garlic.
  3. Liver: Swollen, yellow, soft, fatty and easily ruptured.
  4. Kidneys: Enlarged, greasy, yellow.
  5. Heart: Flabby, pale and shows fatty degeneration.
  6. Lungs: Fat emboli may be found in the pulmonary arterioles and capillaries.

Histopathology: Toxic hepatitis with extensive necrosis, ballooning degeneration, and steatosis.

Explanation of other options:

Datura poisoning (Option A): Causes anticholinergic symptoms—dry mouth, mydriasis, delirium.

Cocaine poisoning (Option B): Causes vasospasm, myocardial infarction, and seizures.

Opium poisoning (Option D): Produces CNS depression, pinpoint pupils, and respiratory failure.

Key Takeaway:
Yellow fatty liver on autopsy is a classical finding in phosphorus poisoning.

questions.text: A 45-year-old factory worker employed in matchstick manufacturing presents with toothache, jaw swelling, and multiple discharging sinuses in the mandible. Examination reveals necrosis of the jaw bone. Which of the following poisons is most likely responsible?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

'Phossy Jaw' is a classical condition associated with chronic exposure to white/yellow phosphorus, especially in matchstick and fireworks industries.

  • Repeated inhalation of phosphorus fumes leads to necrosis of the jaw, most often the mandible.
  • Initial symptoms: Toothache, swelling of jaw, followed by loose teeth and necrosis of gums.
  • Sequestration of bone and discharging sinuses develop, causing foul-smelling pus.
  • This condition is also called "Lucifer’s jaw" or "Glass jaw".
  • Constitutional symptoms include weight loss, anemia, jaundice, and ascites in chronic exposure.

Explanation of other options:

Datura (Option A): Causes anticholinergic toxidrome; no effect on bone.

Arsenic (Option B): Causes peripheral neuropathy, hyperpigmentation, and raindrop skin-not jaw necrosis.

Thallium (Option D): Causes alopecia and painful neuropathy; no bony changes.

Key Takeaway:
Phossy jaw (osteonecrosis of the jaw) is a hallmark of chronic phosphorus poisoning, especially seen in matchstick workers.

questions.text: A farmer is brought to the emergency department after ingesting a rodenticide. He is vomiting, and the vomitus is noted to be luminescent in the dark and smells of garlic. He also has evidence of liver and kidney damage. These characteristic findings are pathognomonic for poisoning with which substance?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The combination of a garlicky odor and luminescence of vomitus or feces (due to oxidation in the presence of air) is the pathognomonic sign of Yellow Phosphorus poisoning.

  • Yellow phosphorus appears as a soft, waxy, white or yellow crystalline solid.
  • It has a garlic-like odor and is highly combustible, emitting a greenish glow in the dark (phosphorescence).
  • It is luminescent due to slow oxidation when exposed to air.
  • It is highly toxic and causes multi-organ damage, especially hepatotoxicity, leading to fatty liver degeneration and hemorrhages.
  • Even small amounts can be fatal if ingested, and it is also carcinogenic with cutaneous exposure.

Explanation of other options:

Aluminum phosphide (Option A): While it also has a garlicky or fishy odor, it does not cause luminescent vomitus. Its primary toxicity is profound, refractory cardiovascular collapse.

Thallium (Option B): This heavy metal poison does not have a characteristic odor. It classically causes a triad of gastroenteritis, painful neuropathy, and alopecia.

Warfarin (Option C): This is an anticoagulant rodenticide that causes toxicity by inhibiting vitamin K-dependent clotting factors, leading to hemorrhage. It does not have the features described.

Key Takeaway:

Yellow phosphorus is the only poison that is waxy, luminescent, and emits garlic odor.

questions.text: Patient presented with bony pain and proteinuria. Which metal is likely to be associated with it?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Chronic poisoning by Cadmium manifests with painful bony lesions, proteinuria and golden yellow discoloration of teeth.

Signs and Symptoms of cadmium poisoning:

Toxicity by inhalation is far greater than by ingestion.

On inhalation: Symptoms develop usually after 4-8 hours. They are influenza-like and similar to those seen in metal fume fever. It is characterized by sneezing, sore throat, irritant cough, nausea, excessive salivation, metallic taste, headache and cyanosis ('cadmium blues'). After a latent period of 24-36 hours, chemical pneumonitis develops which is characterized by fever, dyspnoea, bronchospasm and pleuritic chest pain, along with tachycardia, oliguria and noncardiogenic pulmonary edema.

On ingestion: Symptoms occur in 1 hour. These are increased salivation, nausea, vomiting, cramps in the abdomen, diarrhoea, myalgia, collapse, and rarely death.

Chronic exposure: Causes anosmia, yellowing of teeth (cadmium ring formation), emphysema, bone pain, fractures with osteomalacia (itai-itai disease or ouch-ouch disease is the most severe form) and chronic renal failure (hypercalciuria, proteinuria, azotemia). In males, it decreases libido, fertility and serum testosterone level, and in females, the function of ovary and development of oocytes may be inhibited. Hypertension and hypochromic anaemia may be seen.

Cadmium is said to be carcinogenic, and increased incidence of lung, prostrate, pancreas and bladder carcinoma has been reported.

Explanation of other options:

Mercury (Option A): Causes tremors, gingivitis, and renal damage but lacks prominent bone manifestations.

Lead (Option B): Associated with anemia, encephalopathy, and colic—not osteomalacia or proteinuria.

Arsenic (Option C): Causes GI symptoms, Mees' lines, and peripheral neuropathy—not bony pain and proteinuria.

Key Takeaway:
Cadmium toxicity presents with bony pain and proteinuria, especially in industrial workers—classic for Itai-itai disease.

Explanation:

Cadmium causes proximal tubular necrosis.

Postmortem findings in cadmium poisoning:

  1. GIT: Mucous membranes of the oesophagus, stomach and intestines are congested and inflamed.
  2. Lungs: Pulmonary edema and emphysema. There may be degeneration and/or loss of bronchial and bronchiolar epithelial cells.
  3. Heart and liver: Fatty degeneration.
  4. Kidneys:Proximal tubular necrosis (interstitial nephritis in chronic cases).
  5. Brain: Congested.

Explanation of other options:

Distal tubular necrosis (Option B): Less commonly involved in cadmium poisoning.

Polyneuritis (Option C): Typically seen with arsenic or lead toxicity.

Cirrhosis (Option D): Chronic arsenic, not cadmium, can lead to hepatic cirrhosis.

Key Takeaway:
Cadmium toxicity leads to proximal tubular necrosis, resulting in renal impairment with characteristic proteinuria and tubular dysfunction.

questions.text: Cardiac arrythmias, myalgia and flaccid quadriplegia are characteristic of poisoning by:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Cardiac arrythmias, myalgia and flaccid quadriplegia are characteristic of poisoning by Barium carbonate.

Signs and symptoms of Barium carbonate poisoning:

The most characteristic features are areflexia and paralysis. Barium induces hypokalaemia. (Ba2+ ion is a muscle poison).

  1. GIT: Nausea, vomiting, salivation, abdominal pain and diarrhea.
  2. Muscular system: Tingling sensation, tremors, cramps, stiffness of the muscles, paralysis of the tongue and larynx, myoclonus, myalgia, flaccid quadriplegia.
  3. CVS: Hypertension, arrhythmia, ectopic beats, ventricular fibrillation, irregular pulse, shock, cardiac arrest.
  4. RS: Pulmonary edema, respiratory failure.
  5. CNS: Mydriasis, vertigo, headache, confusion, convulsions.

Explanation of other options:

Aluminium phosphide (Option B): Causes circulatory collapse, severe metabolic acidosis, and myocarditis.

Mercury (Option C): Causes tremors, gingivitis, and renal toxicity—not characteristic paralysis or arrhythmias.

Thallium (Option D): Causes painful polyneuropathy and alopecia.

Key Takeaway:
Barium carbonate poisoning presents with hypokalemia, arrhythmias, and flaccid paralysis—classic features aiding early diagnosis and management.

questions.text: Blue lines are not seen in poisoning by
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Blue lines are not seen in Arsenic poisoning.

Burton's or Burtonian line:

Morphology:

  • A stippled blue line (or bluish black) is seen on gums in 50-70% cases of chronic lead poisoning (Plumbism/saturnism).

Characteristics:

  • More common in upper jaw
  • Appears within a week of exposure
  • Not seen in edentulous persons
  • Removal from exposure obliterates line gradually
  • More common in persons with bad orodental hygiene, carious teeth

Mechanism:

  • Subepithelial deposition of black Pb granules
  • Bad oral hygiene-food sticking in gums decomposition → H2S formed → Reacts with Pb in tissues forms PbS [black]

Differential diagnosis:

  • Similar lines seen in poisoning by bismuth, copper, iron, mercury and silver (due to formation of sulphides of each). In copper poisoning, it is green in colour, known as Clapton’s lines

Key Takeaway:
Arsenic poisoning does not produce gingival blue lines, unlike lead, bismuth, mercury, and silver.

questions.text: Acute copper sulphate poisoning manifests with:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Acute copper sulphate poisoning manifests with Acute hemolysis

Signs and symptoms of acute copper sulphate poisoning:

GIT: Metallic taste, ptyalism (increased salivation), burning pain in stomach, thirst, colicky abdominal pain, nausea, eructation and repeated vomiting. Vomitus is greenish- blue. Diarrhea with much straining, hemorrhagic gastroenteritis.

Renal: Oliguria, hematuria, hemoglobinuria, albuminuria and uremia.

Hepatic: Jaundice, tender hepatomegaly, hepatic encephalopathy.

Muscular system: Cramps or spasms of legs, paralysis of limbs, rhabdomyolysis.

CVS: Breathing difficulty, cold perspiration, methemoglobinemia, hypotension, tachycardia, circulatory collapse and shock.

CNS: Frontal headache, lethargy, drowsiness, insensibility, irreversible coma and death occurs.

  • Hemolysis and hemoglobinuria are present in severe cases.Individuals with G-6-phosphate deficiency may be at increased risk of hematologic effects of copper.
  • Multiorgan dysfunction syndrome may occur.
  • Early death is attributed to hypotension and shock, late death to hepatic and/or renal failure.

Copper poisoning affects the erythrocytes, the liver, and the kidneys in the order. Intravascular haemolysis appears 12-24 h following ingestion. Haemolytic anaemia is caused either by direct cell membrane damage or indirectly as a result of the inactivation of enzymes which protect against oxidative stress.

Key Takeaway:
Acute hemolysis is the hallmark feature of acute copper sulphate poisoning, typically appearing within 12–24 hours of ingestion.

questions.text: A person was found dead with bluish green frothy discharge at the angle of mouth and nostrils. Probable cause can be:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Postmortem findings in copper poisoning

  1. Skin may be yellow due to jaundice.
  2. Greenish-blue froth from the mouth and nostrils
  3. Mucous membrane of the mouth and tongue may have bluish or greenish-blue tinge.
  4. Internally, some discoloration is present in the mucous membrane of the esophagus and stomach.
  5. Stomach: Gastric mucosa is congested with desquamation and haemorrhages at places.
  6. Small intestine: Mucosa (upper part) may show necrosis.
  7. Liver: Soft and fatty. It shows centrilobular necrosis and biliary stasis.
  8. Kidneys: It may show acute proximal tubular necrosis.

Haemoglobin casts may be seen in the tubules.

Explanation of other options:

Arsenic poisoning (Option A): Presents with hemorrhagic gastroenteritis and dehydration; froth is not bluish-green.

Mercury poisoning (Option C): Causes stomatitis, renal failure; not typically associated with greenish froth.

Lead poisoning (Option D): Chronic condition with anemia, blue lines on gums; not an acute frothing presentation.

Key Takeaway:
Bluish-green frothy discharge at mouth and nostrils is pathognomonic of copper sulphate poisoning.

questions.text: Black foot disease is caused by:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Black foot disease is caused by chronic poisoning by Arsenic

Blackfoot disease is a characteristic vascular disease associated with long-term exposure to inorganic arsenic. It occurred in areas of Taiwan with elevated arsenic in drinking water. The patients suffer severe systemic arteriosclerosis with black, mummified dry foot-gangrene in severe cases.

Signs & symptoms of Chronic Arsenic Poisoning:

  • Earliest sign is emaciation.
  • Catarrhal changes – Rhinitis, lacrimation, conjunctivitis, bronchial catarrh
  • Hyperpigmentation of palms and soles is seen. It mimics Addison’s disease.
  • Hyperkeratosis of palm and soles.
  • Rashes resembling fading measles
  • Rain drop brown pigmentation
  • Black foot disease is caused. It is a gangrenous change.
  • Aldrich-Mee’s lines (leukonychia) are seen (Multiple, transverse parallel white lines in the nails. Takes about 30 days after first exposure. Also seen in thallium poisoning).
  • Cancer (A precancerous lesion called Bowen’s disease, Basal cell carcinoma, Small cell carcinoma, Ca lung and Ca bladder)

Explanation of other options:

Mercury (Option A): Causes tremors, gingivitis, and renal toxicity—not associated with gangrene.

Cadmium (Option B): Primarily affects kidneys and bones—not vascular gangrene.

Lead (Option D): Causes anemia, neuropathy, Burton’s line—not gangrene.

Key Takeaway:
Blackfoot disease, a gangrenous vascular condition, is a hallmark of chronic arsenic poisoning.

Reference:

ScienceDirect – Blackfoot disease topic page: https://www.sciencedirect.com/topics/blackfoot-disease

questions.text: Not a symptom of inorganic chronic lead poisoning is:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Diarrhoea is not a symptom of inorganic chronic lead poisoning.

Signs & symptoms of chronic lead poisoning:

(Mnemonic: ABCDEFGHI)

  1. Anaemia/Anorexia/Arthralgia/Abortion/Atrophy of optic nerve
  2. Basophilic stippling/Burton's line
  3. Colic/Constipation/Cerebral edema
  4. Drop (wrist, foot)
  5. Encephalopathy/Emaciation/Erectile dysfunction
  6. Facial pallor/Foul smell of breath/Fanconi syndrome
  7. Gonadal dysfunction/Gout-like picture (Saturnine gout)
  8. Hypertension/Headache/Hallucination
  9. Infertility/Insomnia/Irritability
  • Pain areas: In the abdomen or joints
  • Gastrointestinal: Constipation,nausea, or vomiting
  • Developmental: Learning disability or slow growth
  • Whole body: Fatigue or loss of appetite
  • Behavioural: Hyperactivity or irritability
  • Also common: Baby colic, headache, insomnia, or memory loss

Explanation of other options:

Constipation (Option A): Classical symptom due to autonomic nervous dysfunction.

Insomnia (Option B): Common neuropsychiatric manifestation.

Anorexia (Option D): Frequently reported in chronic exposure.

Key Takeaway:
Constipation, not diarrhoea, is a hallmark gastrointestinal symptom in chronic lead poisoning.

Explanation:

In early stages of lead poisoning, there may be polycythemia with polychromatophilia, but later there is anaemia with karyorrhexis and dyserythropoiesis (punctate basophilia, Cabot's rings, reticulocytosis, poikilocytosis, anisocytosis), nucleated red cells and increase in mononuclear cells in peripheral blood and ringed sideroblasts in bone marrow.

However, polymorphonuclear cells and platelets are decreased. RBC count comes down to 3.5 million/dl and haemoglobin level to 6.5 g%.

Lead poisoning has been known to cause sideroblastic anemia by inhibiting several enzymes involved in heme synthesis, including δ-ALA dehydratase, coproporphyrin oxidase, and ferrochelatase.

Visual Aid: Lead inhibition in heme synthesis

Image: Enzymes inhibited by lead (in red) → δ-ALA dehydratase, Ferrochelatase.

Key Takeaway:
Ringed sideroblasts in bone marrow are characteristic of lead-induced sideroblastic anemia due to enzyme blockade in heme synthesis.

questions.text: Which of the following heavy metal poisoning strictly affects motor nerve?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Chronic lead poisoning strictly affects motor nerve. Sensory nerves are not clinically affected

Lead:

  • Lead palsy (Drops): It is a late and uncommon phenomenon, seen in <10% of cases.
  • It is common in adults than in children, and males are particularly affected.
  • It occurs due to degeneration of nerves and atrophy of muscles as a result of interference with phosphocreatine metabolism.
  • The muscle groups affected are those most prone to fatigue.
  • Sensory nerves are not clinically affected.
  • There may be tremors, numbness, hyperesthesia and cramps before the actual muscle weakness.
  • Later, the extensor muscles of wrist (wrist drop) are affected, but the deltoid, biceps, anterior tibial (foot drop), and rarely muscles of eye or intrinsic muscles of hand and foot are also affected.

Arsenic:

  • Arsenic poisoning can cause peripheral neuropathy. The lesion is a sensory-motor axonopathy.
  • The classic finding is a peripheral neuropathy involving sensory greater than motor neurons in a symmetrical, stocking glove distribution].
  • Those cases may at first seem indistinguishable from Guillain-Barré syndrome (acute inflammatory demyelinating polyneuropathy)
  • Cranial nerves are rarely affected, even in severe poisoning.

Mercury:

  • Peripheral neuropathy from mercury exposure most commonly involves distal latency sensory slowing for short-term exposures, followed by motor slowing for more long-term exposures.
  • Inorganic and elemental mercury exposures are more likely to cause peripheral nervous system complaints and findings.

Thallium:

  • Subacute thallium neuropathy evolves more slowly, beginning more than a week after exposure.
  • The neuropathy is characterized by sensory greater than motor deficit.
  • All modalities are affected (proprioception, light touch, and pin).
  • Walking may be affected early on, primarily due to the painful paresthesias in the feet.

Explanation of other options:

Arsenic (Option A): Causes sensory > motor neuropathy in a stocking-glove distribution.

Mercury (Option B): Causes sensory then motor slowing in peripheral nerves.

Thallium (Option D): Predominantly sensory neuropathy with painful paresthesias in feet.

Key Takeaway:

Lead poisoning uniquely causes pure motor neuropathy, especially wrist drop.

questions.text: Minamata Bay disease refers to chronic toxicity with:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Minamata Bay disease was due to chronic organic mercury intoxication.

Minamata disease:

  • It is due to chronic organic mercury intoxication caused by eating contaminated fish and shellfish.
  • In Minamata Bay (Japan), a factory discharged inorganic mercury into the water.
  • The mercury was methylated by bacteria and subsequently ingested by fish.
  • Local villagers ate the fish and began to exhibit signs of chronic mercury poisoning.
  • Symptoms include disturbances in hand coordination, gait and speech, chewing and swallowing difficulties, visual blurring, tremors, rigidity, seizures and clouding of consciousness.

Explanation of other options:

Ergot (Option A): Causes ergotism with vasoconstriction, gangrene, and hallucinations.

Dhatura (Option B): Causes anticholinergic toxidrome—dryness, delirium, and mydriasis.

Organophosphorus (Option C): Leads to acute cholinergic symptoms—salivation, lacrimation, diarrhea.

Key Takeaway:
Minamata disease is caused by chronic methylmercury poisoning from consumption of contaminated seafood.
